item.title: Trump Extends Tariff Deadline to August as He Unveils New Rates
item.description: President Donald Trump unveiled the first in a wave of promised letters that threaten to impose higher tariff rates on key trading partners, including levies of 25% on goods from Japan and South Korea, and signed an executive order holding off the new duties until Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Catherine Lucey

item.title: Lawyers Say New Evidence Challenges Trump on El Salvador Prisons
item.description: Lawyers for Venezuelans sent to a prison in El Salvador claim new evidence “contradicts” the US government’s claims that Salvadoran officials, not the Trump administration, have legal authority over the men.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Prison officers stand guard at maximum security penitentiary CECOT (Center for the Compulsory Housing of Terrorism) on April 4, 2025 in Tecoluca, San Vicente, El Salvador.

item.title: Rubio Heads to Malaysia for Summit Under Shadow of Tariffs
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio is set to make his first trip to Asia as the top US diplomat this week, heading to a regional summit in Malaysia a day after President Donald Trump threatened a new 25% tariff on the country and several others.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: Signage for the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Photographer: He Guowei/VCG/Getty Images

item.title: Carney’s Cabinet Searches for Spending Cuts as Defense Bill Grows
item.description: Canada’s finance minister has asked members of cabinet to find billions of dollars in spending cuts as the government looks for ways to pay for a larger defense budget and capital projects.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, right, and Minister of National Defence David McGuinty meet with Canadian troops at the Fort York Armoury in Toronto, on June 9.

item.title: Second Ship Hit in Red Sea After Earlier Houthi Attack
item.description: A second vessel was attacked by five rocket-propelled grenades in the Red Sea near Yemen, just a few hours after Houthis claimed responsibility for an earlier attack on a ship sailing in the same area, making voyages through the key region dangerous again.
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Hatem, Sherif Tarek, Catherine Cartier

media:content.media:description: The Magic Seas vessel.

item.title: Trump Gives Himself Overtime Period to Cut Trade Deals
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, White House correspondent Josh Wingrove looks at the president’s latest tariff threats and deadline. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

item.title: Carney Says New Oil Pipeline Proposal Likely in Canada
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said a new oil pipeline to Canada’s West Coast is “highly likely” to be proposed as a nation-building project, which could mean it becomes part of Ottawa’s push to fast-track major developments under new legislation.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, speaks at LeBreton Flats on Canada Day in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Canada Day, which has been celebrated since 1868, also coincides this year with the 60th anniversary of the Canadian flag.

item.title: Spending Law’s Medicaid Limits Spur Planned Parenthood Suit
item.description: Planned Parenthood is suing the Trump administration over its new multitrillion-dollar tax and spending law, claiming it unconstitutionally targets the group by barring its health centers from receiving Medicaid reimbursement for reproductive health care.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Sign at entry of Planned Parenthood clinic, This clinic is in Pullman Washington. (Photo by: Don and Melinda Crawford/UCG/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: EU Rushes to Conclude a Framework Trade Deal With US This Week
item.description: The European Union is seeking to conclude a preliminary trade deal with the US this week that would allow it to lock in a 10% tariff rate beyond an Aug. 1 deadline as they negotiate a permanent agreement.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Operations at the HHLA Hamburg Container Terminal Altenwerder in the Port of Hamburg.

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: US Removes Terrorist Designation of Syrian Rebel Group HTS
item.description: The US State Department is revoking the foreign terrorist designation of an Islamist rebel group that played a key role in downfall of Bashar Al-Assad’s regime in Syria, a week after President Donald Trump ordered the termination of sanctions on the country.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Soldiers from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham march through Umayyad Square during a mourning demonstration in Damascus, on Dec 27.

item.title: Four Dead in Kenya Protests as Police Shut Capital City Down
item.description: At least 11 people were killed in violent clashes between Kenyan police and protesters demanding the removal of President William Ruto.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks, David Herbling

media:content.media:description: A man walks past a barbed wire barricade set up by police outside parliament ahead of possible Saba Saba Day demonstrations in Nairobi on July 7, 2025. Kenya marked its fight for democracy on July 7, 2025 with police blocking main roads in Nairobi ahead of potential protests, after last month's demonstrations descended into violent clashes. Saba Saba Day marks the uprising on July 7, 1990 when Kenyans demanded a return to multi-party democracy after years of autocratic rule by then-president Daniel arap Moi. (Photo by Tony KARUMBA / AFP) (Photo by TONY KARUMBA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Newest US Navy Aircraft Carrier Faces 20-Month Delivery Delay
item.description: Delivery of the Navy’s newest aircraft carrier, the USS John F. Kennedy, is likely to be pushed to March 2027 from this month because of production challenges, according to a newly disclosed budget document.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

item.title: University of Notre Dame Loses Endowment Tax Shield in GOP Bill
item.description: It looked like the University of Notre Dame would be safe from a Republican proposal to raise taxes on college endowments.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rembert

media:content.media:description: The entrance to the University of Notre Dame campus in South Bend, Indiana.

item.title: EU to Conclude Deals to Give UK, Canada Access to Defense Loans
item.description: The European Union will propose bilateral agreements with the UK and Canada as soon as the end of July, which would give them access to the bloc’s new €150 billion ($176 billion) loan fund for defense production, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: A production line of ammunition Photographer: Dominika Zarzycka/NurPhoto/Getty Images

item.title: Lula Tells Trump to Mind Own Business After Bolsonaro Comments
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva told Donald Trump to mind his own business after the US leader rushed to the defense of embattled former President Jair Bolsonaro, who is facing charges that he attempted a coup.
item.dc:creator: Travis Waldron, Leda Alvim, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro

item.title: ‘Irresponsible’ Trump Tariff Threat Draws Ire of BRICS Host Lula
item.description: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva joined South Africa in blasting Donald Trump for his threat to slap extra tariffs against the BRICS, escalating a spat with the US leader during the final day hosting the 10-member group.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Simone Iglesias, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa attends a BRICS summit session in Rio de Janeiro, on July 6.

item.title: Trump Plans Texas Trip This Week to Survey Flood Devastation
item.description: President Donald Trump will travel to Texas this week to survey first-hand the devastation from extreme floods that have left at least 91 people dead and scores still missing, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: A resident walks through debris during search and rescue efforts in Center Point, Texas, on July 06. Photographer: Brandon Bell/Getty Images

item.title: S&P Sees Trump Tax Law Hurting State and Hospital Balance Sheets
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new budget bill is expected to push almost 12 million Americans off their health insurance, creating long-term financial issues for states and health-care providers, according to a S&P Global report.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: An examination room is seen at the Oscar Center in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Dec. 7, 2016. The Oscar Center runs in partnership with Mount Sinai Health Systems providing primary care services and health and wellness programs. Photographer: Kholood Eid/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Immigration Crackdown Sparks Fresh Unlawful-Conduct Claims
item.description: President Donald Trump’s escalating immigration crackdown has sparked a new round of lawsuits alleging illegal seizures by masked federal agents, as well as violations of US privacy rights and environmental laws.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Agents from Immigration and Customs Enforcement detain an immigrant after a court hearing at the Connecticut Superior Court in Stamford, Connecticut, on July 3 Photographer: John Moore/Getty Images

item.title: Boston University Cuts 120 Staff After Trump Funding Squeeze
item.description: Boston University is eliminating staff and reducing spending as the school grapples with the Trump administration’s push to reshape higher education and a pullback in research funding.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: The Charles Hayden Memorial Building on the Boston University campus in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Friday, Aug. 25, 2023. The US Supreme Court effectively barred universities from using race as a factor in university admissions, marking the start of a new era in higher education and rolling back decades of precedents.

item.title: Ghost Factories Are a Warning Sign for Green Manufacturing’s Future
item.description: Rollbacks of clean-energy credits in Trump’s tax bill add to the sector’s challenges as project cancellations rise.
item.dc:creator: Saijel Kishan

media:content.media:description: A plot of land for sale where Kore Power’s project had previously been announced.

item.title: KLM to Lend Pilots to Dutch Air Force for Fighter Jet Duties
item.description: Dutch flag carrier KLM agreed to lend pilots to the country’s air force, increasing the airline’s cooperation with the defense ministry after criticism it was poaching military aviators.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: A Dutch Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II fighter jet.

item.title: Trump Immigration Enforcer Says ICE Will Boost Raids in New York
item.description: Tom Homan, the border czar for President Donald Trump, said that immigration agents will ramp up arrests in New York City as part of a broader crackdown on sanctuary jurisdictions that limit cooperation with federal authorities.
item.dc:creator: Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: Tom Homan, White House border czar, speaks to members of the media outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. Homan, asked about concerns from farmers that immigration enforcement is harming them, says there is a right and wrong way to hire.

item.title: Trump Unveils Tariff Demands on Indonesia, Bangladesh

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Port of Cape Town in South Africa. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Guyana Opposition Taps Aubrey Norton as Its Presidential Candidate
item.description: Guyana’s main opposition group announced veteran politician Aubrey Norton as its presidential candidate, promising to use growing oil production to deliver higher wages and other social programs.
item.dc:creator: Denis Chabrol

media:content.media:description: Aubrey Norton Source: US Embassy Guyana

item.title: Fresh From One Crisis, South Africa’s Ramaphosa Faces Another
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa is lurching from one crisis to another.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa during a plenary session at the BRICS Summit in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on July 6.

item.title: Donohoe Retains Eurogroup Role to Push Currency’s Ascendancy
item.description: Paschal Donohoe won reelection as president of the euro area’s group of finance ministers, retaining a leading role in the region’s efforts to enhance the profile of its common currency.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michal Kubala, Daniel Basteiro, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe, president of Eurogroup, during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025. As Donald Trump prepares to be sworn in as president today, Europe's leaders are bracing for the first batch of executive orders and their potential impact on the region. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Says It’s Making Progress on Framework Trade Deal With US
item.description: The European Union said it’s closing in on a framework trade agreement with the US after the head of the bloc’s executive arm, Ursula von der Leyen, held a call with President Donald Trump on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michael Nienaber, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Harbor ferry boats pass the Port of Hamburg in Hamburg, Germany, on Monday, Feb. 3, 2025. A global trade war is heating up and Germany’s biggest seaport, like the country at large, is steeling itself for what may be to come.

item.title: Russia Probes Suicide After Ex-Transport Minister Found Dead
item.description: Former Russian Transportation Minister Roman Starovoit died in an apparent suicide, the country’s investigative committee said in a statement on Monday, hours after he was dismissed from his post.
item.dc:creator: Greg Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Roman Starovoyt in May.
